heading: online interpreter
subheading: according to the hitchhiker's guide to the galaxy, a babel fish is "small, yellow, and leechlike, and probably the oddest thing in the universe." odd, that is, because douglas adams's book says that if you stick a babel fish in your ear you can understand any language. on-the-fly language translation, à la babel fish, is […]
author: paul kedrosky
text: according to on-the-fly language translation, à la babel fish, is the holy grail of linguistics. altavista's search site (a standard test of any translator is to ask it to translate a chosen phrase, then have it iterate back and forth, watching for signs of impending meaninglessness. i tried the test using english and german and the always-popular saying, "the rain in spain stays mainly in the plain." things held remarkably stable, other than a troublingly teutonic bit wherein the rhyming "plain" became the less ear-pleasing "horizontally aligned."if you're particularly persistent, as i am, the translation eventually stops changing. the final version? "the rain in spain falls mainly into horizontal geentsprochen." i don't know what geentsprochen is, but i've been having these bad dreams about yellow, slimy things that ooze out of closets at night. babel fish, perhaps? street cred phone talkon priests of naturerings of truthvideogame history 101sorceress of softwarethe return of campechoes of a communityaffirmations barbiewormboonline interpretereconomics 1, humanity 0maximize the mediumreadmenot all sex is bad sexdriving creative businesscolors for your padcontributors
